title: Evolution of Spines in Cacti
evolutionary_explanation: Ancestral cacti developed spine-like structures as plastic responses to herbivory. This defensive adaptation constructed a niche with reduced predation, leading to genetic assimilation of the spine-producing trait.
validity_analysis: The explanation aligns with evidence that spines evolved as a defense against herbivores, with niche construction reinforcing the trait. Cacti spines are modified leaves or buds, evolving under herbivory pressure.

relevant_schemas.description: Spines modified the environment by deterring herbivores, creating a low-predation niche that favored spine-producing traits.
Initial spine-like structures arose as plastic responses to herbivory, later genetically assimilated.

title: Evolution of Running Ability in Cheetahs
evolutionary_explanation: Ancestral cheetahs that were slightly faster had access to more prey in open habitats. By selecting this niche, they created selection pressures favoring faster developmental pathways, gradually evolving extraordinary running ability.
validity_analysis: Niche selection in open habitats driving speed is well-documented in cheetah evolution. Cheetahs’ speed (up to 60-70 mph) evolved in savannas, where it provided a hunting advantage.

relevant_schemas.description: Faster cheetahs selected open savanna niches, creating selection for speed.
Developmental pathways biased toward faster muscle and bone growth were favored.

title: Evolution of Haustoria in Dodder
evolutionary_explanation: Ancestral dodder plants likely developed haustoria-like structures as plastic responses to contact with host plants. This parasitic adaptation allowed them to construct a new nutritional niche, leading to genetic assimilation of haustoria-producing traits.
validity_analysis: The parasitic lifestyle of dodder supports this explanation, with haustoria evolving for nutrient uptake.

relevant_schemas.description: Haustoria enabled a parasitic niche, reducing competition for nutrients.

title: Loss of Flight Ability in Penguins
evolutionary_explanation: Ancestral flying birds exploiting aquatic feeding niches experienced selection favoring swimming over flight. Through plasticity, wing structures shifted function to underwater 'flight,' with genetic accommodation solidifying flightlessness.
validity_analysis: Penguins’ shift to swimming is a classic example of niche-driven trait loss, supported by fossil evidence.

relevant_schemas.description: Aquatic niches favored swimming over flight.

title: Loss of Vision in Cave Salamanders
evolutionary_explanation: Salamanders colonizing dark cave environments experienced relaxed selection for vision. Plastic reductions in eye development were favored, leading to genetic assimilation of eyelessness.
validity_analysis: Vision loss in cave salamanders is a well-documented regressive adaptation, supported by genetic and ecological studies.
sources: Evolution of eye development in caves
The Evolution of Gene Expression Underlying Vision Loss

validity_analysis: Toxins in snails (e.g., cone snails) evolved for defense/predation, supported by studies on venom evolution.
